page.title: 04Tim's working day
page.content: I work a farm of 250 acres, producing corn and beef. Winter barley, hay and bagged silage are grown for the beef cattle - spring barley, wheat and winter beans for the open market. We are trying out teazels, borage and lupins. In 1949 the farm employed 13 horses and 7 men. Now there is one man, Tim and 3 tractors. I get up at 6.45a.m. Choose 5 steers to be sold at Bridgwater market, feed rolled barley and bed down the steers under cover. Halfway through breakfast the bell rings - 5 cattle have jumped the stone wall of their field - we move them down to the moor and fresh pastures. I attend a planninbg meeting for next year's agricultural show, then call on a contractor to organise round bales for silage. After some welding and fencing I have supper, watch the 'weather' and go to bed at 10.30p.m.
